Bert wrote:

> Let me begin by thanking you J.B. for all the time and effort you put
> into this discussion group.

You are most welcome.

> As for this parameterized testing, I think this is a brilliant
> concept.  However, I'm seeing that all the examples deal with a single
> set of data and a single test method.

Correct on "single set of data"; incorrect on "single test method." The 
Parameterized Test Case pattern works best for a single test method, 
because it recommends implementing runTest(). The Parameterized Test 
Suite pattern is meant to go further: it combines parameterization with 
collecting the test*() methods into a default test suite.

Referring to the example, ComparabilityTestCase defines a handful of 
test methods, and not just one.

> Take your example below.  You pass 4 parameters to the constructor of
> your test class and then execute testReturnValues for the number of
> fixtures you've set up (5 in the example).
> 
> Now take my example below.  I have 3 distinct test methods.   Each of
> the 3 methods requires a different set of parameters.  

"different set of parameters" => different fixtures, using the 
definition of "fixture".

In general, if you have two tests that operate on different objects, 
then they should use different fixtures. That means one of two things:

  * Put them in separate TestCase classes, *or*
  * Put them in the same TestCase class, but /do not/ extract fixture 
setup code into setUp()

As a result, I would implement your hypothetical example as three 
separate Parameterized Test Case classes.

> class MyClassTest extends TestCase {
> RealClass realClase;
> 
> public MyClassTest(String testCaseName) {
>    super(testCaseName);
> }
> 
> public void setUp() throws Exception {
>    realClass = new RealClass();
>    // Do some setup
> }
> 
> public testGetStuff() {
>     realClass.getStuff(param1, param2);
>     // Do your asserts, etc.
> }
> 
> public testUpdateStuff() {
>     realClass.getStuff(param1, param2, param3);
>     // Do your asserts, etc.
> }
> 
> public testDeleteStuff() {
>     realClass.getStuff(param1, param2, param3, param4);
>     // Do your asserts, etc.
> }

Looking on these tests, there is no gain to using Parameterized Test 
Case/Suite. The whole point of the parameterized test patterns is to 
make it easier to write data-driven tests where you're executing the 
same set of tests on multiple rows of data, much like a FIT test.

A simple example is a calculation rule that you want to check on ten 
base cases and twelve boundary cases. Your options are:

  * Write one test method that loops on 22 rows of data and executes the 
test for each row
  * Write 22 test methods, each of which invokes doTest() with the 
different parameters
  * Write a Parameterized Test Case (one test method) or Suite (many 
test methods on the same row of data)

Option #1 gives you the wrong test count, and I care about getting that 
right. It also means that if row #4 fails, then you won't know whether 
rows #5-22 fail. Some people don't care about that; but I do.

Option #2 means I have to write code to add more tests, rather than 
possibly add data to a file.

Option #3 allows me to add tests without adding code, it reports each 
row of data as its own test (which is logically correct) and stops the 
failure of one test from affecting the others.
